titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Vervon Orval Watts papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Hoover Institution Archives Staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-08-20T14:52-0700
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

did.abstract: Correspondence, speeches and writings, notes, instructional materials, research materials, clippings, and other printed matter relating to economic conditions in the United States and economic theory, especially laissez-faire economics.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], V. Orval (Vervon Orval) Watts papers, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1983.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Taught at various colleges and universities, including Clark University, Harvard University, Wellesley, Antioch College, Carlton College, Claremont Men's College, Pepperdine University, and Campbell College
Author, Why Are We So Prosperous?
Economic counsel, Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce
Author, Do We Want Free Enterprise?
Editorial director, Foundation for Economic Education (FEE)
Director of economic education and chairman of the Division of Social Studies, Northwood University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Vervon Orval Watts papers document the life and career of a conservative economist, academic, and opinion maker. An early critic of the New Deal, Watts maintained a lifelong commitment to laissez-faire principles, opposing government intervention in the economy and most social welfare programs. He sought to popularize these ideas by communicating them to a broad audience. His papers are largely comprised of writings, research materials, writings by others, and printed matter.

The extensive Speeches and Writings series contains many of Watts' articles, speeches, and pamphlets, as well as several monographs that he wrote or edited. The series also includes work that Watts did as a publicist and speechwriter for the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce, including the texts of many lectures that he gave. The collection also has an extensive Subject File, comprised largely of clippings and articles, that reflects Watts' many research interests. Prior to serving as an economic advisor to organizations, Watts had a long teaching career, and the Academic File contains course materials, lecture notes, and syllabi relating to classes he taught at several institutions. Additionally, the academic file has a number of materials from Watts' time as a student, including papers that he wrote, as well as reading and lecture notes.

The collection also has a significant number of Speeches and Writings by Others, mainly on economic issues. There are also many pamphlets collected by Watts in the Printed Matter series, largely written by conservative authors.

did.unittitle: Article on interest rates and production,
"An Economist's Reaction to the Proposals of Wm. P. Hapgood,"
"Spiritual and Moral Aspects of Business ('Material') Prosperity,"
Article on inequality and Henry Wallace,
Lecture outlines, Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce,
Report of the Committee on Production for Use,
"Prospects for New Industries in Southern California,"
"Robin Hood Economics Not What the United States Wants,"
"Money, Currencies, and Credit in Free Markets,"
The United Nations: Road to War,
"Recent Developments of New Economic Theories Relevant to Problems of Public Policy: Keynesian Economics,"
Should We Strengthen the United Nations?,
Reactions to President Nixon's Address to the Nation,
"John Steinbeck's The Grapes of Wrath: Marxian Ideology Wrapped in Obscenity,"
Examination questions, assignments, and course requirements,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relates to the old-age pension movement in California in the 1930s. Includes correspondence.

did.unittitle: Friedman, Milton and George J. Stigler,
"The Current Housing Problem: Ceilings or Roofs?," article drafts,

scopecontent.p: Includes letter from Ayn Rand to William C. Mullendore.
